questions.question: Question 1: What type of hypersensitivity reaction is seen in systemic lupus erythematosus?
questions.explanation:
Type III hypersensitivity reaction (immune complex deposition) is seen in systemic lupus 
erythematosus. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune condition in which autoantibodies are 
directed against a part of the nucleus such as double-stranded DNA, histone, ribonuclear proteins, 
etc. The presence of these autoantibodies leads to the deposition of immune complexes and 
activation of the complement system.

questions.question:
Question 2: Patients with which of the following complement deficiencies are at an increased risk of 
developing systemic lupus erythematosus?
questions.explanation:
C1q complement deficiency is a risk factor for the development of systemic lupus erythematosus 
(SLE). Risk factors for SLE are: • Genetic • Genetic defects resulting in C1q, C2, C4 complement deficiencies • Presence of HLA DR3 • Mutation in the TREX1 gene • Environmental • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection • Oral contraceptive pills/ hormone replacement therapy • Smoking • Prolonged exposure to silica 547 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Anti-nuclear antibodies are required for the diagnosis of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) are required for the diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus. ANAs are autoantibodies that bind to the contents of the cell nucleus. They are present in > 
•5% of patients with SLE. A positive antinuclear antibody ( ANA ) test with a titer of at least 1:™0 
is the obligatory entry criterion along with the additive criteria in š clinical and 3 immunologic 
domains. If a total of >10 points achieved, it is indicative of SLE according to 201• EULAR/ACR 
Classification Criteria for Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) Most sensitive antibody for SLE: ANA Most specific antibody for SLE: Anti smith > Anti dsDNA ANA may also be positive in the other options but it is not a criterion for diagnosis of these 
conditions. The following antibodies are specific for their respective autoimmune conditions. • Scleroderma (option A): Anti-topoisomerase I(Scl-š0) and anti-centromere antibodies highly 
specific for Systemic sclerosis. • Rheumatoid arthritis (option C): RF and anti-CCP antibodies • Sjogren syndrome (option D): Anti-Ro, Anti-La

questions.question:
Question 4: A 25-year-old marathon runner presents with complaints of joint pain and rashes over the 
face. She says the rashes appear on exposure to the sun. On physical examination, a butterfly 
rash is seen over her face sparing the nasolabial folds. Which of the following antibodies will 
you evaluate to screen this patient? 540 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The best 
screening test in this condition is to evaluate for the presence of antinuclear antibodies (ANAs).

questions.question:
Question 5: A school teacher presented with painful oral ulcers, photosensitive rashes, and arthralgia. 
Presence of which of the following antibodies would be diagnostic of her condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of oral ulcers, photosensitive rash, and arthralgia is suggestive of 
systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Anti-Sm antibodies are most specific for SLE and hence their 
presence is diagnostic of this condition.

questions.question:
Question 6: An SLE patient is found to have a butterfly rash. Which of the following is an incorrect 
statement regarding this finding?

options.a: Most common acute rash in SLE
options.c: Increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma

questions.explanation:
Butterfly rash or malar rash in a patient with SLE is not associated with an increased risk of 
squamous cell carcinoma. It is the most common type of acute skin rash seen in SLE. It is a photosensitive, erythematous, 
and scaly rash that is prominent over the cheeks and the nose. It spares the nasolabial folds. Common causes of malar rash are as follows: • Erysipelas • Cellulitis 548 
Sold by @itachibot • Systemic lupus erythematosus • Rosacea • Pellagra • Dermatomyositis

questions.question: Question 7: What is the most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE?
questions.explanation: The most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE is pleuritis, with or without pleural effusion. The most common manifestations of different systems involved in SLE are: • Musculoskeletal- arthritis and arthralgia • Skin- photosensitivity • Kidneys- proteinuria • Neurologic- cognitive impairment • Cardiac- pericarditis • Pulmonary- pleuritis • Hematologic- anemia

questions.question:
Question 8: 541 
Sold by @itachibot A 40-year-old man with history of SLE presented to your OPD with shortness of breath. It is 
associated with chest pain that worsens on inspiration. On auscultation, you notice a pleural 
friction rub. Investigations reveal the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with elevated hemidiaphragm and no evidence of ILD on chest 
CT is suggestive of shrinking lung syndrome (SLS), which is a rare complication of systemic lupus 
erythematosus (SLE). It is characterized by dyspnea and episodes of pleuritic chest pain. These symptoms occur in the 
absence of pleural or parenchymal involvement. PFT shows decreased lung volume with a restrictive pattern, and DLCO is often reduced. 
Radiological investigations show an elevated hemidiaphragm with no evidence of ILD. The following X-ray shows shrinking lung syndrome. 549 
Sold by @itachibot Pulmonary manifestations seen in SLE are: • Pleuritis with or without pleural effusion- most common pulmonary manifestation. • Lupus pneumonitis - It is the inflammation of the lung tissue (pneumonitis) due to SLE (lupus). • Interstitial lung fibrosis • Shrinking lung syndrome • Intra-alveolar hemorrhage

questions.question:
Question 9: What is the most common neurological manifestation seen in patients with systemic lupus 
erythematosus?
questions.explanation:
The most common neurological manifestation seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus 
(SLE) is cognitive impairment. It can manifest as impaired memory and reasoning. Other common neurological manifestations 
in SLE are psychosis, depression, and seizures. The most common manifestations of different systems involved in SLE are: • Musculoskeletal- arthritis and arthralgia • Skin- photosensitivity • Kidneys- proteinuria • Neurologic- cognitive impairment • Cardiac- pericarditis • Pulmonary- pleuritis • Hematologic- anemia 550 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A young girl is being evaluated for low mood, anhedonia, weight loss, and insomnia since past 
1 month. On examination, multiple hesitation marks were seen on her left forearm. She was 
diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) one year back. Which of the following 
autoantibodies is associated with this presentation?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of depression in a patient with SLE. It is associated with 
anti-ribosomal P antibodies. Antiribosomal P antibody is associated with psychosis or depression in SLE.

questions.question:
Question 11: What is the most common cardiac manifestation seen in patients with systemic lupus 
erythematosus?
questions.explanation:
Pericarditis is the most common cardiac manifestation seen in patients with systemic lupus 
erythematosus. Other cardiac manifestations include: • Myocarditis • Libman-Sacks endocarditis. Patients with SLE are at an increased risk for myocardial infarction, usually due to accelerated 
atherosclerosis. The most common manifestations of different systems involved in SLE are: • Musculoskeletal- arthritis and arthralgia • Skin- photosensitivity • Kidneys- proteinuria • Neurologic- cognitive impairment • Cardiac- pericarditis • Pulmonary- pleuritis • Hematologic- anemia

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is a feature of arthritis in SLE?
questions.explanation:
Non-erosive arthritis is a common feature of arthritis in SLE. Features of arthritis in SLE are: • Symmetrical and polyarticular arthritis • A predilection for the small joints of the hand (the proximal interphalangeal and carpal joints) • Non-erosive and deforming arthritis (reducible) In contrast to rheumatoid arthritis which is characterized by erosive, deforming joint 
involvement, SLE has non-erosive and deforming arthritis (reduciable).

questions.question:
Question 13: A young woman who is a known case of SLE develops proteinuria. The doctor suspects lupus 
nephritis and performs a renal biopsy. It shows the presence of wire loop appearance without 
glomerular proliferation. In which class of lupus nephritis will you categorize this patient's 
biopsy findings?
questions.explanation:
551 
Sold by @itachibot Wire loop appearance without glomerular proliferation is seen in diffuse lupus nephritis (Class 
IV). The capillaries are thickened due to the subendothelial deposits and appear as wire loops. It is the 
most common and most severe form of lupus nephritis. Renal involvement is common in patients with SLE. The majority of the patients will present with • Proteinuria, nephrotic syndrome • Microscopic hematuria, hypertension • Urinary casts • Abnormal renal function tests- elevated serum creatinine • Low C3 and C4 levels

questions.question:
Question 14: A 40 year old female presented to the OPD for her annual routine check-up. she is a patient of 
SLE diagnosed a decade ago, among the given options what is the most common cause of 
death in such patients?

Question 15: 543 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following drugs is recommended for all patients with SLE?
questions.explanation:
Hydroxychloroquine is recommended for all patients with SLE. It decreases the symptoms, 
reduces flares and organ damage. Important drugs used in the management of SLE are: 552 
Sold by @itachibot • NSAIDs- used for a shorter period to reduce pain and fever. They are not used in all patients 
because of the increased risk of atherosclerosis and renal injury. • Hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine- should be used in all patients with SLE • Glucocorticoids • topical glucocorticoids- in mild skin lesions • systemic steroids- in severe skin lesions and organ involvements. • Immunosuppressive agents- used in combination with glucocorticoids in severe skin lesions and 
organ involvement. They help to reduce the dose and toxicity of glucocorticoids. Important agents 
are: • Methotrexate • Azathioprine • Mycophenolate mofetil and cyclophosphamide- immunosuppressive agents of choice in renal 
involvement. • Biologic drugs- like belimumab and rituximab are used when there is no response to 
conventional drugs.

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient with a history of SLE presented with hematuria and proteinuria. Investigations 
revealed elevated creatinine and low C3, C4 levels. He was unresponsive to steroid therapy 
and his physician prescribed him belimumab for further management. What is the 
mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lupus nephritis. Belimumab is a BAFF inhibitor used in 
patients with lupus nephritis who do not show response to initial therapy with steroids. Belimumab is a human monoclonal antibody that inhibits the soluble form of a B cell survival 
factor (known as BLyS or BAFF) which promotes the formation of memory B cells and 
autoantibodies. Belimumab inhibits this factor and therefore is used in the management of SLE. It is used in combination with either cyclophosphamide or MMF in patients with lupus nephritis 
who do not show response to initial therapy with steroids. CD20 is an antigen present on the B cells. Rituximab is an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody that is 
used in patients who are resistant to the standard therapies.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 60-year-old man presented with fever, malaise, skin rashes, and arthralgia. On further 
evaluation, his serology was positive for ANA and anti-histone antibodies. Use of which of the 
following drugs could have led to this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with positive ANA and anti-histone antibodies point towards a 
diagnosis of drug-induced lupus erythematosus. Hydralazine which is a vasodilator is associated 
with the development of drug-induced lupus erythematosus. Drug-induced lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune condition caused due to exposure to certain 
medications. It completely resolves after the causative drug is discontinued. Important drugs 
associated with this condition are: • Sulfonamides • Hydralazine 553 
Sold by @itachibot • Isoniazid • Infliximab • Procainamide • Propylthiouracil • ACE inhibitors • Thiazides • TNF-alpha antagonists

questions.question: Question 18: What is the ratio of occurrence of drug-induced lupus erythematosus in females and males?
questions.explanation:
The female to male ratio in drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE) is 1:1. The female to male ratio in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is •:1. Drug-induced lupus erythem

questions.explanation:
Renal involvement is rare in drug-induced lupus erythematosus. Drug-induced lupus erythem

questions.question: Question 20: Antiphospholipid syndrome is associated with all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Thrombocytosis is not associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). On the contrary, 
thrombocytopenia is seen. APS is an autoantibody-mediated condition that is characterized by arterial thrombosis, venous 
thrombosis, and recurrent fetal loss. These autoantibodies bind to the phospholipids present on 
the endothelial cells and activate coagulation and thrombus formation. Important manifestations of venous thrombosis are: • Deep vein thrombosis of legs • Pulmonary embolism • Livedo reticularis • Cerebral venous thrombosis Important manifestations of arterial thrombosis are: • Stroke, transient ischemic attacks • Retinal artery thrombosis • Myocardial ischemia • Libman-Sacks endocarditis- due to the vegetations formed by platelet fibrin microthrombi • Leg ulcers, gangrene of the digits Important obstetric manifestations are: • Preeclampsia • Recurrent fetal loss • Premature birth Important hematological abnormalities are: 555 
Sold by @itachibot • Thrombocytopenia- occurs due to increased platelet aggregation and thrombus formation • Coombs positive hemolytic anemia- seen when autoantibodies attack red blood cells • Thrombotic microangiopathic syndromes- thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and 
hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)

questions.question:
Question 21: A 34-year-old woman comes for evaluation of recurrent fetal losses. She has had 4 
spontaneous abortions, all of them at <10 weeks of gestational age, and has a history of 
deep vein thrombosis. Which of the following antibodies is not useful in making a diagnosis 
in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history of >3 spontaneous abortions at <10 weeks of gestational age along 
with a history of deep vein thrombosis suggests a diagnosis of antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). 
Anti beta-2 microglobulin is not useful in diagnosing this condition. For the diagnosis of antiphospholipid syndrome, high titers of one or more of the following three 
antibodies should be demonstrated along with at least one clinical symptom of thrombosis or 
pregnancy complications: • Lupus anticoagulant (LA) - most specific • Anticardiolipin (aCL) antibodies - most sensitive • Anti-beta-2 glycoprotein antibodies

questions.question:
Question 22: A 40-year-old man presented with painful swelling of his right calf muscle. The clinical test 
shown below was positive. Investigations revealed elevated D-dimer, high titres of lupus 
anticoagulant and anti-cardiolipin antibodies. You would use all of the following drugs for his 
management except: 545 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given findings of positive Moses' sign with elevated D-dimer, lupus anticoagulant, and 
anti-cardiolipin antibodies are suggestive of antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). Glucocorticoids 
are not useful in the general management of APS, they are used only in the treatment of 
catastrophic APS. Squeezing of the relaxed calf muscles from side to side is painful as the thrombosed deep veins in 
the calf are always tender. This test is known as Moses’ sign. The clinical manifestations in APS occur due to the activation of coagulation and thrombus 
formation. Therefore, anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents are the mainstays in the treatment. 
Important drugs used are: • Warfarin- is an anticoagulant that inhibits vitamin K dependant epoxidase. • Low molecular weight heparins (LMWH)- warfarin cannot be used in pregnancy due to its 
teratogenicity. In these situations, LMWH is used for anticoagulation. • Aspirin- is an antiplatelet agent. • Hydroxychloroquine- is an immunomodulatory agent that can be used to prevent recurrent 
thrombosis. • Statins Note: The only condition where corticosteroids are beneficial is catastrophic APS. It is a 
life-threatening rapidly progressive thromboembolic disease involving simultaneously three or 
more organs. It is seen in very few patients. 556 
Sold by @itachibot 557 
Sold by @itachibot Rheumatoid Arthritis
